column4: Is it GIMP 2.4 pronounced "GIMP 2 dot 4" or "GIMP 2 point 4"?
depends where you are from
I mean for someone that speaks english natiely, what sounds best?
again, depends where you are from -- here in england, i've known people to say "2point4" or "2dot4" - i prefer the former as it represents a numeric version
well it doesn't actually; GIMP 2.12 is a later version than GIMP 2.4, so it should not be interpreted as a decimal number
gimp is weird then
same goes for Blender, Linux and all other programs I can think of
i dunno what blender is .. but it's not true of linux .. 2.4 < 2.6,  2.6.18 < 2.6.24, etc
so same there
i believe it was 2.6.02 back then
no, it was 2.6.2 (google and see)
your world breaks apart now, doens't it ;)
not really :) i don't perform any arithmetic on these numbers

break the number down into major release, minor release and revision increment -- then it doesn't have to confuse you - but then again, not all authors/vendors follow this standard of versioning, it depends really (like i said initially)
I'm not confused at all, I was just wondering how it is pronounced by someone that natievely speaks englsih
varies from person to person, preference to preference -- but i guess if a gimp developer refers to gimp 2.4 as "gimp 2dot4" then it's officially that
nah, most GIMP developers doesn't speak English nateivly
it's not a matter of them speaking english -- it's about them naming their babies, if i were called Juan (and pronounced it with a J) then that's what you really ought to call me, no? :)
2 dot 4 is not part of the name though
call it what you will -- it really is a no-op
that's to ensure there is no spurious disk access when the kernel is initially loading (bugs, hardware issues, etc) - the kernel remounts the root volume as rw later on in the bootstrap.
